awd_abstract_narration:
The Computer Science for All movement focuses on providing all students, including those with special needs, with computational thinking and computer science learning opportunities. This project is a Researcher Practitioner Partnership (RPP) between Braintree Public Schools (BPS) and EdGE at TERC. The shared purpose of this RPP is to build a strong foundation for the teaching and learning of Computational Thinking (CT) in upper elementary and middle schools throughout BPS, and in doing so, to inform a scalable and generalizable model of personalized CT education for a broad audience of diverse learners in grades 3-8 with cognitive differences. To meet this shared purpose, the RPP will design and develop CodePlay--a suite of digital tools, activities, assessments, and professional development experiences that infuse CT into existing curriculum in grades 3-8. CodePlay tools include a Playlist Generator for teachers to build individualized playlists of activities that guide learners through a CT learning progression, layered with opportunities for interest-driven and customized learning. CodePlay activities are immersed within science, math, and other existing disciplinary content; and prepare learners for project-based learning using coding tools such as Scratch and BlocksCAD (for 3D printing). 

A year of design-based implementation research (DBIR) will enable the RPP to curate and co-design classroom activities that support teaching and learning of CT for a diverse audience of learners in grades 3-8. A subsequent pilot study of about forty classes in BPS will study how CodePlay can support CT teaching and learning in elementary and middle school classes throughout the district. CodePlay will leverage several facets of EdGE's previous NSF supported research including: a growing partnership with BPS, expertise from leaders in CT research, a preliminary CT learning progression and curriculum activities; and a unique automated assessment data architecture called Data Arcade. The RPP will also co-design professional development and community support structures to build capacity that can sustain systemic change within the district.

por.por_cntn:
The CodePlay project was a research-practice partnership (RPP) between TERC and Braintree Public Schools (BPS) with the shared goal to support all upper elementary- and middle-school learners across the district in developing and applying Computational Thinking (CT)?the ways of thinking required to use, design, and innovate with today?s and tomorrow's? technologies. The TERC team of designers and researchers worked alongside the three K-12 STEM directors in the district to facilitate a co-design process among TERC and BPS. The RPP co-designed tools, materials, and teacher education experiences that build capacity and teaching strategies to support CT learning throughout STEM and other disciplines in elementary and middle school.

 

Intellectual Merit:

The CodePlay materials development and implementation directly were used by over 30 elementary and middle school teachers in BPS and their students during the granting period. The co-design process engaged teachers in their own professional growth in knowledge of CT, while also providing innovative materials for their students. The CodePlay design research and co-design process involved regular workshops and meetings with the BPS teachers and TERC team, working together to build activities that worked in the classroom and met the teaching and learning goals of the project. These meetings (4 PD days each school year with classroom visits and work sessions in between) were a professional growth experience for the 30 teachers, as well as a design research process for the materials.

Working closely with the RPP teachers, we produced a set of teaching and learning materials for grades 3-8 that infuses CT into a broad array of topics in the BPS curriculum. These include (but are not limited to) activities designed with teachers from across the district with:

  • Elementary general education class activities on CT using common examples from everyday life, 
  • CT-infused Math and Science activities, 
  • Game-based learning activities,
  • Integrated Information Technology activities, and 
  • English language learning activities. 

The CodePlay materials use a CT framework emphasizing problem decomposition, pattern recognition, abstraction, and algorithm design with digital and non-digital activities in STEM.

The CodePlay research study attempted to examine the growth in CT practices for students in CodePlay classes as compared to the general student population, and also examine if any differenced found varied for students with Individual Education Plans for academic difficulties (or equivalent) as compared to the general student population. Our final year of data collection, which was the first full year of implementation and therefore where we anticipated we first might be able to measure a significant impact of CodePlay, was in Spring 2020. Schools were closed for much of the intended data collection period. When they re-opened virtually, and even into Fall 2020, they were in no position to continue with our intended data collection. As such, unfortunately, there are no meaningful findings from the longitudinal research.

 

Broader Impacts:

We we worked with a cadre of over 30 teachers in BPS grades 3-8 who continue using materials from CodePlay with their students and continue sharing the materials with others. At the suggestion of the BPS Co-PIs, during the project we added a Teacher Coach to the team who supported elementary teachers in their implementation of CT. The role of the Teacher Coach was to provide ideas and support to classroom teachers for the integration of CT into their curriculum. This position was partially funded by the grant for this year and is has been continued by the district after the granting period. We also worked with the RPP co-design teachers to package and prepare the materials in such a way that BPS staff could access and modify the materials themselves in perpetuity.

The materials that have been provided for ongoing use in the district are in Google Docs for easy ongoing access by the RPP teachers and our team. In addition, prototype products such as a co-designed elementary math and CT interactive called NumberFactory has been the foundation of future research and development in our current project Including Neurodiversity in Foundational and Applied Computational Thinking (INFACT, Dept of Ed, U411C190179) and other projects.
